ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is really a great class. Useful, fun, and you will have a nice final product. Great to take as an undergrad even though you will not get any credits for it (worth it).
Take it! You won't regret it.

Would definitely recommend if you care to learn how to use the machine shop tools and might need to make something yourself for research/project etc. The time commitment is reasonable and provides a nice, rewarding escape from the classroom. A good investment of time if you're at all interested!
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to take a shop class.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I now have the skills to make experimental apparatus parts out of metal. If that's not a crucial skill to experimental science, I don't know what is.

This course gave me a deeper understanding of the work and precision that goes into fabricating metal parts, ultimately increasing my understanding and appreciation for scientific instrumentation as a whole. I expect that I'll be able to use the skills I learned (and access gained) to fabricate/modify necessary parts in the lab for either mine or even a labmates' future work.
Machine skill did not help me directly but I know others who have taken this course and then applied the skills to their own research projects.
I'll probably be using the machine shop a lot for my lab. This makes no direct contribution to my research, but knowing how to make the tools used in my research makes it possible in the first place.
